question.name: 19.3.5.2 Engineering example
question.questiontext:
Example

An LC circuit with sinusoidal input

The differential equation governing the flow of current in a series LC circuit when subject to an applied voltage \(v(t) = V_0 \sin \omega t\) is

\[L\frac{\mathrm{d}^2i}{\mathrm{d}t^2} + \frac{1}{C} i = \omega V_0 \cos \omega t.\]

Obtain its general solution.

Solution

The homogeneous equation is

\[L\frac{\mathrm{d}^2i_\text{cf}}{\mathrm{d}t^2} + \frac{1}{C} i_\text{cf} = 0.\]

Letting \(i_\text{cf} = e^{kt}\), we find that the auxiliary equation is

\[Lk^2 + \frac{1}{C} = 0,\]

so that \(k = \pm i / \sqrt{LC}\). Therefore, the complementary function is:

\[i_\text{cf} = A \cos \frac{t}{\sqrt{LC}} + B \sin \frac{t}{\sqrt{LC}},\]

where \(A\) and \(B\) are arbitrary constants.

To find a particular integral try \(i_\text{p} = E \cos \omega t + F \sin \omega t\), where \(E\) and \(F\) are constants. We find:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d}i_\text{p}}{\mathrm{d}t} &= -\omega E \sin \omega t + \omega F \cos \omega t\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}^2i_\text{p}}{\mathrm{d}t^2} &= -\omega^2 E \cos \omega t - \omega^2 F \sin \omega t \end{aligned}\]

Substitution into the inhomogeneous equation yields:

\[L(-\omega^2 E \cos \omega t - \omega^2 F \sin \omega t) + \frac{1}{C}(E \cos \omega t + F \sin \omega t) = \omega V_0 \cos \omega t\]

Equating coefficients of \(\sin \omega t\) gives:   \(-\omega^2 LF + (F/C) = 0\)

Equating coefficients of \(\cos \omega t\) gives:   \(-\omega^2 LE + (E/C) = \omega V_0\)

Therefore, \(F = 0\) and \(E = CV_0 \omega / (1 - \omega^2 L C)\). Hence, the particular integral is

\[i_\text{p} = \frac{CV_0 \omega}{1 - \omega^2 LC} \cos \omega t.\]

Finally, the general solution is:

\[i = i_\text{cf} + i_\text{p} = A \cos \frac{t}{\sqrt{LC}} + B \sin \frac{t}{\sqrt{LC}} + \frac{CV_0 \omega}{1 - \omega^2 LC} \cos \omega t\]
